This app is made for Project 97 of the 2018 Electrical and Computer Engineering Part IV Projects at the University of Auckland. The app's focus is to provide automated emergency callouts when anomalies in heart rate patterns are detected. 

 Heart rate anomaly detection is conducted via a trained back-propagation neural network. Data is gathered from Physionet, with samples containing the 1024 RR Intervals before the onset of ventricular tachycardia. From research, this ultimately gives a 52 second buffer time from detection to callout. 

 Ventricular tachycardia is an important condition to detect because it naturally leads to life-threatening conditions such as ventricular fibrillation, in which late detection poses an extremely high risk of death. 

 The neural network architecture and weights are trained via Python (via Keras - a wrapper of the TensorFlow API) with 95% accuracy. They are imported into this app for decision making based off heart rate readings from a Polar H7 heart rate monitor. From research, this monitor is highly accurate relative to standard ECG monitors in getting accurate R-R intervals (r = 0.996). 

 You can also connect a programmed NRF52 device which can cycle through different heart rate patterns akin to different diseases, to observe the neural network's real-time accuracy. 

 


****Any BLE device connected on app needs to be paired prior. Bluetooth 4.0 is required for BLE.
